text:
John Davison Rockefeller (July 8, 1839 – May 23, 1937) was an American business magnate and philanthropist, best known as the founder of the Standard Oil Company. Born in Richford, New York, he grew up in a modest family and moved to Cleveland, Ohio, at a young age. He attended the University of Chicago but left before completing his degree to join his brother's work in a produce commission firm.

In 1863, Rockefeller moved to Cleveland and co-founded the oil refining company, Standard Oil, with his partners. The company rapidly gained market dominance by acquiring or driving out competitors through aggressive pricing strategies and shrewd business tactics. In 1870, Rockefeller was appointed as the General Manager of Standard Oil.

By 1879, he had amassed a staggering fortune of $900 million, making him one of the wealthiest men in the world. At its peak, Standard Oil controlled approximately 90% of the oil refining industry in the United States. Rockefeller's business methods, which involved the creation of a complex web of companies with shared management, drew criticism and eventually led to the enactment of the Sherman Antitrust Act in 1890. This led to the dissolution of Standard Oil in 1911.

Throughout his life, Rockefeller remained a private and reclusive individual, shying away from the spotlight. Despite his controversial business tactics, he contributed greatly to American philanthropy, donating significant portions of his wealth to causes such as education, medicine, and scientific research. Rockefeller donated more than $540 million to educational, cultural, and scientific institutions, including the founding of the University of Chicago, the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now Rockefeller University), and the Rockefeller Foundation.

Rockefeller's wealth and influence have left a lasting impact on the United States, with Standard Oil as its legacy. Today, Rockefeller is still remembered as one of America's most successful and controversial entrepreneurs. His fortune and philanthropy set the stage for a new era of charitable giving that still influences

He established the University of Chicago, the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now Rockefeller University), and the Rockefeller Foundation. Through these organizations and more, he helped fund advancements in public health, science, and education.

John D. Rockefeller's immense wealth and philanthropy have left an indelible mark on American society and the world. His pioneering spirit in the business world and his dedication to social causes have made him a significant figure in the annals of American history.

The youngest of five brothers, Rockefeller's early life was shaped by hard work and a strong familial bond. His father, William Avery Rockefeller Sr., was a station master and his mother, Eliza Davison, came from a prominent family.

Rockefeller pursued his education at the University of Rochester, but left before completing his degree to work at a general store in Cleveland, Ohio. Rockefeller's business acumen and competitive strategies helped him establish Standard Oil as an international powerhouse. He used a variety of tactics to consolidate his control over the oil industry, including aggressive pricing, acquiring competitors, and building an extensive network of pipelines and refineries. By the 1890s, Standard Oil controlled an estimated 90% of the U.S. oil market, leading to significant criticism and a public outcry.

In response to the antitrust movement, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 1911 that Standard Oil must be dissolved into 34 smaller companies. Rockefeller, however, retained a majority of the stocks and continued to exert influence in the newly formed companies.

In addition to his business achievements, Rockefeller was also a philanthropist. He donated over $500 million to various causes throughout his lifetime, including the establishment of the University of Chicago, the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, and the Rockefeller Foundation. He believed in the importance of investing in social programs and institutions that would benefit society at large.

Rockefeller passed away on May 23, 1937, in Rockefeller Center in New York City. He left behind a legacy of both controversy and philanthropy, and is remembered as one of the wealthiest and most influential figures in American history.

Despite coming from a humble background, Rockefeller pursued higher education. He attended the University of Rochester, where he studied business and philosophy. After graduating in 1857, Rockefeller entered the business world, working briefly as a bookkeeper for his brother's trading business.

In 1859, Rockefeller began working with his older brother, Maurice, in their investment ventures. The brothers participated in the Cleveland Oil Exchange and began to trade whale oil. After the whaling industry started to decline, they shifted their focus to refining and selling crude oil.

With the establishment of Standard Oil, John D. Rockefeller became one of the richest men in the world. The company's aggressive business tactics allowed it to quickly dominate the oil refining industry, and by 1879, it controlled more than 90% of all oil refining in the United States.

He focused on cost-cutting and efficiency, which allowed the company to undercut competitors on price and offer lower-cost oil to consumers. Who is that person, John D. Rockefeller? Born on July 8, 1839, in Richford, New York, United States, John Davison Rockefeller would go on to become one of the world's richest and most influential businessmen, most notably as the founder of the Standard Oil Company.

Rockefeller grew up in a modest family, the eldest of six children. His father, William Avery Rockefeller, was a salesman who later became a traveling salesman of paint, varnish, and other goods. The young Rockefeller showed a propensity for business from a young age, working in a produce store during his teenage years.

After graduating from the Cleveland's University Circle's Western Reserve Eclectic Institute (now known as the Case Western Reserve University), Rockefeller entered the business world as a partner in a small produce store. His next venture, Rockefeller & Andrews, a small produce and wood business in Cleveland, expanded as the city grew in size.

In 1863, Rockefeller founded Standard Oil, a company that focused on the refinement and distribution of oil products. He used innovative business practices, such as horizontal integration, vertical integration, and economies of scale to gain control over the oil industry. By 1879, Standard Oil owned more than 90% of the United States' oil refineries and pipelines.

Rockefeller's success attracted both praise and criticism. He was known for his philanthropic efforts, supporting education, medical research, and the arts. In 1896, he established the University of Chicago, which bears his name, and became a major benefactor to many organizations, including the Rockefeller Foundation, the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research (now Rockefeller University), and the Rockefeller University Hospital.

Despite his philanthropy, critics decried his business practices as monopolistic and exploitative. The Sherman Antitrust Act was passed in 1890 to limit monopolies and promote fair competition, leading to Standard Oil's breakup in 1911. Rockefeller's business empire was divided into 34 companies, some of which are still prominent today.

Through acquisitions, favorable railroad rates, and vertical integration, Standard Oil grew exponentially, gaining control over over 90% of America's refining capacity. Despite the public backlash against his business practices, Rockefeller's influence on American industry and economy was undeniable.

Rockefeller, undeterred by the setback, continued to lead Standard Oil of New Jersey and Standard Oil of California, which eventually became part of Chevron and ExxonMobil, respectively.
